docs.lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline.seo: Latest News: Ebola, Same-Sex Marriage, Samsung

byline.original: By ADEEL HASSAN and VICTORIA SHANNON

docs.lead_paragraph: Philadelphia teachers vowed to fight a sudden move by the district Monday that cancels their union contract and requires them to start paying health premiums of $55 to $140 a month.

headline.main: Pennsylvania: Health Costs Imposed on Teachers
headline.print_headline: Pennsylvania: Health Costs Imposed on Teachers

docs.abstract: Philadelphia teachers vow to fight sudden move by district that cancels their union contract and requires them to start paying health premiums of $55 to $140 a month come December.
docs.snippet: Philadelphia teachers vowed to fight a sudden move by the district Monday that cancels their union contract and requires them to start paying health premiums of $55 to $140 a month.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of plans will be canceled before next year, but there are hundreds of millions of Americans with health insurance.

headline.main: Health Plan Cancellations Are Coming, but for Relatively Few
headline.print_headline: Health Plan Cancellations Are Coming, but Not So Many

docs.abstract: The Upshot; people are starting to get letters telling them their health insurance plans have been canceled because of the Affordable Care Act, but the people affected will represent only a small fraction of the population with health insurance.
docs.snippet: Thousands of plans will be canceled before next year, but there are hundreds of millions of Americans with health insurance.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.abstract: Should physician-assisted suicide be more widely available in the United States and what should be the conditions?

docs.lead_paragraph: As China tries to privatize an overburdened public healthcare system, private hospitals face a shortage ... of doctors.

headline.main: Dearth of Doctors Drags on China Private Healthcare Drive
headline.print_headline: Dearth of Doctors Drags on China Private Healthcare Drive

docs.snippet: As China tries to privatize an overburdened public healthcare system, private hospitals face a shortage ... of doctors.

docs.lead_paragraph: Conservative Republican incumbent Renee Ellmers and Democratic ex-entertainer Clay Aiken on Monday each blamed the other's party for dysfunctional government, claimed that they had better ideas to solve the country's problems, and that their opponent would be little more than a tool for party bosses.

headline.main: DC Gridlock Key in Debate for US House Seat in NC
headline.print_headline: DC Gridlock Key in Debate for US House Seat in NC

docs.lead_paragraph: Liberian healthcare workers still plan to stage a go-slow, or work slowdown, to press demands for hazard pay on the front line of the Ebola epidemic, a union leader said on Monday.

headline.main: Liberia Health Workers to Stage Go-Slow for Ebola Hazard Pay
headline.print_headline: Liberia Health Workers to Stage Go-Slow for Ebola Hazard Pay

docs.snippet: Liberian healthcare workers still plan to stage a go-slow, or work slowdown, to press demands for hazard pay on the front line of the Ebola epidemic, a union leader said on Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: The state panel that oversees Philadelphia's cash-strapped public schools abruptly canceled a contract with teachers on Monday, despite nearly two years of labor negotiations, and said teachers would have to begin paying for healthcare benefits.

headline.main: Philadelphia Teachers to Pay for Health Benefits as Contract Axed
headline.print_headline: Philadelphia Teachers to Pay for Health Benefits as Contract Axed

docs.snippet: The state panel that oversees Philadelphia's cash-strapped public schools abruptly canceled a contract with teachers on Monday, despite nearly two years of labor negotiations, and said teachers would have to begin paying for healthcare benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Senator Jeanne Shaheen walked into a roomful of largely Democratic New Hampshire women voters with a simple pitch: She would be more focused on their issues than her challenger, Scott Brown, the former Republican U.S. senator for Massachusetts.

headline.main: In U.S. Senate Battles, Democrats See Votes in Women's Health
headline.print_headline: In U.S. Senate Battles, Democrats See Votes in Women's Health

docs.snippet: U.S. Senator Jeanne Shaheen walked into a roomful of largely Democratic New Hampshire women voters with a simple pitch: She would be more focused on their issues than her challenger, Scott Brown, the former Republican U.S. senator for Massachusetts.
